Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2009 02:03AM TwillNW wrote: I was essentially given the same choice of chemo regimes that you are looking at.  I did some but not a lot of research.  I ended up going with AC+T for the aggressive factor, but the key difference in my case is that I also had three positive nodes.  I did not want to look back at some point in the future and feel like I had "left something on the table" - I wanted to hit the cancer as hard as possible in hopes of never needing to hit it again.  I tolerated the AC+T regime quite well, but I am not prone to nausea nor am I especially sensitive to meds - had Emend and other anti-nausea drugs as part of the infusions and never needed anything else - but I think I am the exception rather than the norm for that.  In hindsight, I think it would have been very beneficial to get a second opinion on which chemo regime - I thought fairly seriously about doing so but not until I was already about a month past surgery and feeling like I needed to get the chemo party started.   In reading many of the threads on these boards, I know I've come across opinions that the TC regime is not really the "kinder, gentler" chemo - it comes with it's own set of side effects that debilitate some people as much or more than AC side effects.  So check into the potential side effects from the two regimes as some may be more or less desirable for you depending on your health history.    Good luck in your decision - this is one of those situations where you wish there was a definitive best choice, but it just doesn't seem to work that way! Tricia

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2009 02:33PM TwillNW wrote: Hey Alyad - Just wanted to jump in and say that I have similar symtoms to yours - also had very similar diagnosis though I did lumpectomy instead of mastectomy.  I had a follow-up with my breast surgeon on 12/21, and he pretty much told me that I have truncal lymphedema on the affected side - breast is slightly larger and "harder" - I have pain that localizes along my side and varying tightness in the armpit area and upper part of the the left arm.  I wasn't surprised that he saw   lymphedema as that was what I had expected, but after reading here, I was pleasantly surprised with his straightforward assessment of the situation.  He has referred me to someone within the same hospital system for an initial appointment although they don't come up as being lymphedema certified in any of the search engines on the lymphedema sites.  I will probably go to the initial appointment but because it's an hour drive, will see what they say and then decide from there what the next step will be.  Must admit - pain has seemed much better since the surgeon called it lymphedema - unclassified pain was much scarier.  Tricia
